A Gift Rejected

Aug 23, 2008

by Jonathan Clausen

Her heavy accent breaks my reverie,
my self-absorption gives way
to abashment.
She is a teacher in the old style:
herself, long ago, a fugitive
from a Holocaust which
once fell upon old Europe.

She firmly corrects my twelve year-old hands
with hers withered and bulging,
with the ravages of wars and age,
attacking this instrument before us both.
I am reminded to hold my fingers properly:
not flat and flaccid,
but arched and ready.

Each week
I have come to dread this moment:
the contrast of her age and mine,
the lack of coolness in it all,
hiding this from my friends
who play baseball instead
or skateboard.

In the opacity of a Grand Piano
our differences are reflected.
As soon as is allowed,
I will leave her for good,
and will later regret
this gift I once rejected.
